overview: How to become a direct access scheme (DAS) motorcycle instructor, how to book your assessment and what it involves
title: Become a direct access scheme (DAS) motorcycle instructor

table.body:
You can apply to the Driving Standards Agency (DSA) to become a direct access scheme (DAS) certified instructor.

##What DAS is 

DAS lets learner riders who are 21 or older practise on motorcycles more powerful than 125cc. They must be supervised at all times by a DAS certified instructor. 

When they pass their practical test on a motorcycle with a power output of at least 35kW, they can ride any size of motorcycle.

##Rules for becoming a DAS instructor

To become a DAS certified instructor you must:

- be 21 or over
- have a Great Britain or Northern Ireland driving licence
- have had a full category A motorcycle licence for at least 3 years
- have passed the 2-day assessment to [become a DSA assessed compulsory basic training instructor](/become-dsa-assessed-cbt-motorcycle-instructor "Become a DSA assessed compulsory basic training (CBT) motorcycle instructor")

^ You’ll have to take a half-day assessment at DSA’s training and development centre in Cardington, Bedfordshire. ^

##When you qualify

When you pass you'll be able to give DAS training.

*[DSA]: Driving Standards Agency
*[DAS]: Direct access scheme
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The direct access scheme (DAS) instructor assessment lasts for half a day. You can book a: 

- morning assessment, which starts at 8:30am
- afternoon assessment, which starts at 1pm

To book your assessment, download the form and send it to the Driving Standards Agency (DSA). There’s no charge for the assessment.

$D [Download ‘Application to attend the direct access assessment’ (PDF, 36KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/dsa-bl/dsa-das-application.pdf "Download ‘Application to attend the motorcycle instructors’ direct access assessment’ (PDF, 36KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

$A

DSA Training and Development Centre
Harrowden Lane
Cardington
Bedford
MK44 3EQ

$A

DSA will contact you to arrange a suitable date when the necessary checks have  been done.

Your  application will be valid for 6 months.

##Not being able to attend

You must contact DSA at the training and development centre if you can’t attend your assessment. You must give at least 7 working days notice.

$C

<cardingtongeneraladmin@dsa.gsi.gov.uk>  
01234 744000  
Monday to Thursday, 8:15am to 5pm  
Friday, 8:15am to 4pm

$C

*[DAS]: Direct access scheme
table.title: How to book your assessment

table.body:
You should make sure that you know the direct access scheme (DAS) guidance notes before you take the assessment.

$D [Download ‘DAS guidance notes’ (PDF, 109KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/dsa-national-driving-riding-standards/dsa-direct-access-scheme-das-guidance-notes.pdf "Download ‘DAS guidance notes’ (PDF, 109KB)"){:rel="external"} $D

You should also study the following official Driving Standards Agency (DSA) publications:

- the Official DSA Guide to Learning to Ride
- the Official DSA Guide to Riding - The Essential Skills
- the Official Theory Test for Motorcyclists
- the Highway Code
- Know Your Traffic Signs

You can [buy these books from The Stationery Office](http://www.tsoshop.co.uk/bookstore.asp?trackid=000177&FO=1270350 "Buy books from The Stationery Office"){:rel="external"} and most high street and online book shops.

*[DSA]: Driving Standards Agency
*[DAS]: Direct access scheme
table.title: Preparing for the assessment

table.body:
You’ll need to bring:

- your valid Great Britain or Northern Ireland driving licence
- your CBT1 card
- your joining instructions and indemnity form
- a fully taxed and roadworthy motorcycle with a power output of at least 35kW
- a full-face safety helmet

% Your assessment will be cancelled if you don’t bring these. %

You’re allowed to bring relevant training aids and preparation material with you.
table.title: What to bring to your assessment

table.body:
There are 3 main sessions in the direct access scheme (DAS) instructor assessment. You'll get a full explanation before the assessment starts.

##Session 1 - theory

This session lasts around 15 minutes. The Driving Standards Agency assessor will play the role of a rider who:

- has done their compulsory basic training (CBT) on a 125cc motorcycle
- is new to riding larger and more powerful motorcycles 

You have to show and tell them the main differences between large motorcycles and the smaller motorcycles used for CBT. You'll do this alongside the motorcycle.

##Session 2 - on-site handling assessment

In this session of the assessment you'll be given the scenario of a rider who has:

- already taken CBT
- difficulties in the basic control of a large motorcycle when riding it on private land

You have to:

- decide how to overcome the difficulties
- give instruction to develop the rider's basic skills off-road

The scenario will include 2 of the following riding skills requiring attention:

- moving off and stopping the bike
- controlled braking
- gear-changing
- slow riding skills
- slow controlled turning (similar to the 'figure of 8' exercise on CBT)

##Session 3 - on-road assessments

This session of the assessment will last for around 1 hour 30 minutes. The assessor will play the part of a trainee. 

^ You'll have to give 3 on-road lessons during this session. ^

The assessor will select the lessons from:

- positioning in normal riding and dealing with bends
- negotiating left and right turns at junctions
- dealing with different types of crossroads
- dealing with town centre riding
- negotiating roundabouts
- dealing with dual carriageways
- dealing with other when following behind and overtaking other vehicles
- moving off from all positions
- riding in areas with a national speed limit
- joining and leaving dual carriageways and following behind other traffic
- dealing with overtaking, meeting, filtering and leaving enough clearance to stationary vehicles
- moving off, the emergency stop exercise, u-turn exercises (pushing and riding) and taking the motorcycle on and off the stand

###During the on-road assessments

During the ride you'll be expected to:

- give any instruction you feel necessary
- correct any riding faults that may occur

^ You can ask the trainee to pull up so that you can give face-to-face instruction or guidance. ^

*[DAS]: Direct access scheme
*[CBT]: Compulsory basic training
table.title: What the assessment involves

table.body:
You’ll be given your result and a debrief at the end of the assessment by the assessor. You’ll be sent confirmation of your result by post.

^ It’s your responsibility to tell your approved training body your result. ^

##Passing the assessment

You’ll be sent an application form to apply to the Driving Standards Agency (DSA) for registration as a direct access scheme (DAS) certified instructor if you pass.

You’ll have to give details of any motoring or non-motoring offences you’ve got within the last 4 years on your application form. These will be taken into account when DSA assess your suitability to be authorised. 

% You aren’t allowed to conduct DAS courses until you’ve got your registration certificate. %

##Failing the assessment

You’ll be sent another DAS assessment application form if you don't pass so you can book again if you want to.

*[DSA]: Driving Standards Agency
*[DAS]: Direct access scheme
